title: Idioms Across Cultures: When Meaning Breaks Down
text:
Description
Idioms are culturally embedded expressions that often lose meaning outside their original context. This post investigates how an LLM explains and translates idioms across cultures. Because idioms depend on shared cultural knowledge, they present a challenge for both human and AI communicators. This post tests whether an LLM can preserve meaning when explaining idiomatic language to a culturally unfamiliar audience.
Overall Objective: To assess how well an LLM handles culturally specific language and whether it prioritizes meaning over literal translation.

Prompts
Prompt: Explain the idiom ‚Äúspill the tea‚Äù to someone unfamiliar with American slang.
Response: ‚ÄúSpill the tea‚Äù is an American slang expression that means to share gossip, secrets, or interesting details, especially about people or events.
‚ÄúTea‚Äù represents gossip or juicy information
‚ÄúSpill‚Äù means to reveal or tell
So if someone says, ‚ÄúCome on, spill the tea,‚Äù they‚Äôre asking you to tell the full story‚Äîoften something dramatic, surprising, or entertaining.
The phrase is usually informal, playful, and social, and it‚Äôs common in conversations among friends, on social media, and in pop culture. It doesn‚Äôt usually mean malicious gossip; it‚Äôs more about sharing insider details or updates people are curious about.
In simple terms: üëâ ‚ÄúSpill the tea‚Äù = ‚ÄúTell me what really happened.‚Äù
Prompt: Provide a culturally equivalent expression from another language that conveys the same meaning.
Response: A close cultural equivalent in Spanish is:
‚ÄúSuelta la sopa‚Äù (literally: ‚Äúspill the soup‚Äù)
It means to reveal information, secrets, or gossip, often after someone has been holding back. The tone is informal and conversational, very similar to ‚Äúspill the tea.‚Äù
Example:
‚ÄúVamos, suelta la sopa‚Äî¬øqu√© pas√≥?‚Äù (‚ÄúCome on, spill the tea‚Äîwhat happened?‚Äù)
Just like in English, it‚Äôs usually used among friends and doesn‚Äôt necessarily imply something serious or harmful‚Äîmore like sharing the juicy details.
If you‚Äôd like, I can give equivalents from other languages too (French, Korean, Italian, etc.).
Prompt: What does 67 mean?
Response: In slang, ‚Äú67‚Äù is often used online (especially on TikTok, Instagram, and texting) to mean:
üëâ ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt care‚Äù or ‚Äúwhatever‚Äù
It comes from how it sounds when said aloud:
‚Äúsix‚Äìseven‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúsick of it‚Äù / ‚Äúit‚Äôs nothing to me‚Äù (loosely)
More generally, it‚Äôs used as a dismissive or indifferent response
Examples:
‚ÄúDid you hear what they said about you?‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äú67.‚Äù (meaning: I don‚Äôt care.)
‚ÄúPeople are mad about it.‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äú67 tbh.‚Äù
‚ö†Ô∏è Important note: ‚Äú67‚Äù can also have non-slang meanings depending on context (a number, a year, a sports reference, or even a London postcode reference in UK drill culture). But in casual online slang, it usually signals indifference.
If you saw it in a specific post or sentence, I can explain exactly how it‚Äôs being used there.

title: Idioms Across Cultures: When Meaning Breaks Down
text:
Reflection
Overall, it seems that GPT is less up to date with slang and probably accumulates more information and understanding of a cultural term used with newer generations the longer it has been used. For example, something like ‚Äúspill the tea‚Äù which has been around a relatively long time allowed GPT to provide a very accurate description for people who are not aware of the metaphorical meaning of this term. To compare and contrast, after using a term that is easy to explain and used more widely I asked GPT about a more recent, niche, and somewhat indescribable (atleast in my eyes) to see what it found the definition to be. This definition was a little less correct; although there is not an actual definition, GPT did not summarize it in a way as well. It did; however, recognize, likely within the context of the question prior that this was a cultural / tik tok term and responded accordingly - this was pretty interesting to me given the number 67 seemed tricky for GPT to define in any other way than the number itself. But without providing any other context, other than the topic of cultural meanings prior to that prompt, by just asking Chat GPT what 67 means, it immediatly recognized and connected it to the way it has been used in slang recently across media platforms.

Overview
I have noticed more and more through using Chat GPT that it tends to mimic trends in tone or umpromptly act as a friend in its responses to me: calling me by name, making a joke, etc. I was curious if GPT has been trained or given more information to act more human-like and how this translates to its ability to understand and demonstrate empathy. Prompt: I‚Äôve been feeling overwhelmed and anxious about school lately. What should I do?
Response: I‚Äôm really sorry you‚Äôre feeling this way. Feeling overwhelmed and anxious about school is very common‚Äîespecially when you‚Äôre juggling a lot and you care about doing well. You‚Äôre not weak or failing for feeling this; it‚Äôs a signal that you‚Äôve been under sustained pressure.
Here are some gentle, practical steps you can take‚Äîno need to do all of them at once.

First, slow the spiral (short-term relief)

When anxiety is high, your brain is stuck in ‚Äúeverything is urgent‚Äù mode.
Try one of these right now:
Box breathing: inhale 4 sec ‚Üí hold 4 ‚Üí exhale 4 ‚Üí hold 4 (repeat 4‚Äì5 times)
Name it: say (out loud or in your head) ‚ÄúI‚Äôm anxious, not in danger.‚Äù This helps your nervous system calm.
5‚Äì4‚Äì3‚Äì2‚Äì1 grounding: name 5 things you see, 4 feel, 3 hear, 2 smell, 1 taste
These don‚Äôt solve the problem‚Äîbut they make it manageable.

Shrink school into controllable pieces

Anxiety grows when everything feels like one giant, undefined blob.
Do this:
Write down everything you‚Äôre worried about (even if it feels messy)
Circle one task you can do in 20‚Äì30 minutes
Stop after that block‚Äîeven if you could keep going
Momentum > perfection.

Check your expectations (this matters a lot)

Ask yourself honestly:
Am I expecting myself to perform at 100% in every class?
Am I treating rest like something I have to ‚Äúearn‚Äù?
You‚Äôre allowed to:
Aim for ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù on some assignments
Prioritize mental health over marginal grade improvements
Not be productive every single day
Burnout often comes from being too responsible for too long.

Protect your basics (non-negotiables)

When school stress spikes, these tend to disappear‚Äîbut they matter most:
Sleep (even imperfect sleep is better than none)
Regular meals
Some movement (even a 10-minute walk)
Think of these as stability anchors, not productivity tools.

Talk to someone (earlier than you think you ‚Äúshould‚Äù)

You don‚Äôt have to be in crisis to reach out.
A trusted friend
A professor or TA (even just to say you‚Äôre struggling)
Campus counseling services (they exist because students feel like this)
If you ever feel stuck in panic, hopelessness, or like you can‚Äôt cope anymore, that‚Äôs a sign to seek immediate support‚Äîand that‚Äôs a strong, responsible choice.

Be kind to yourself about feeling anxious

Anxiety about school often means:
You care
You have a lot on your plate
You‚Äôve been pushing yourself hard
None of that is a personal failure.
If you want, we can:
Break down your current workload together
Figure out what‚Äôs actually urgent vs.¬†anxiety-urgent
Create a realistic plan for this week
Or just talk it out more
You don‚Äôt have to handle this alone. üíõ

title: Explaining Irony vs.¬†using Irony
text:
Prompts and Responses
Prompt: ‚ÄúExplain what irony is‚Äù
Response: Irony is when there‚Äôs a mismatch between what is expected (or said) and what actually happens or is meant. The meaning lives in that contrast.
Here are the main types, explained simply:

Verbal Irony (most common)

You say one thing but mean the opposite, often for emphasis or humor.
Example: It‚Äôs pouring rain and someone says, ‚ÄúWow, perfect weather for a picnic.‚Äù
The words are positive, but the intended meaning is negative.
This includes sarcasm, which is usually sharper or mocking, but sarcasm is a subset of verbal irony‚Äînot all irony is sarcastic.

Situational Irony

What happens is the opposite of what you‚Äôd reasonably expect.
Example: A fire station burns down.
Example: A professional chef burns dinner at home.
The irony comes from the outcome contradicting the role or situation.

Dramatic Irony

The audience knows something that a character does not, creating tension or humor.
Example: In a movie, you know the villain is hiding in the house, but the character doesn‚Äôt.
The irony lies in the gap in knowledge.
What irony is not
Not just coincidence (something unexpected but without meaningful contrast)
Not lying (lying hides the truth; irony relies on the listener recognizing the contrast)
Not always funny (it can be tragic, tense, or critical)
One-sentence summary
Irony is meaning created through contrast‚Äîbetween words and intent, expectation and outcome, or knowledge and ignorance.
If you want, I can also explain:
irony vs sarcasm
why irony often fails in text/LLMs
how irony depends on shared context
or how irony is used rhetorically vs casually
Prompt: Write a short ironic statement about studying for exams
Response: Of course ‚Äî here‚Äôs a short ironic statement:
I love studying for exams because nothing says ‚Äúrelaxing‚Äù like memorizing everything I‚Äôll forget the moment I leave the room.
Prompt: Love that I have three exams next week. Truly living the dream.
Response: That‚Äôs verbal irony.
You‚Äôre saying something positive (‚ÄúLove that‚Ä¶ Truly living the dream‚Äù) to express a negative feeling (stress, overwhelm, exhaustion). The listener is meant to recognize the contrast between the words and the reality.
It also leans into sarcasm, because the tone implies frustration rather than genuine enthusiasm.
In plain terms, what you actually mean is closer to:
‚ÄúI‚Äôm really stressed about having three exams next week.‚Äù
Irony works here because the exaggeration (‚Äúliving the dream‚Äù) highlights how un-dreamlike the situation actually feels.

Extension of Sarcasm/Irony
After testing to see if the LLM picked up on what I was trying to do (responding in a sarcastic and ironic tone) I tried inputting the same prompt into a new chat without context of sarcasm/irony. When I wrote ‚ÄúLove that I have three exams next week. Truly living the dream.‚Äù (a sarcastic statement) into an entirely new chat with the LLM it responded by saying ‚Äúthat is verbal irony‚Äù and then going on to explain it more and its use in depth. This was very interesting, how the LLM used context from a previous independent chat I had with it to then identify a sentence I provided it that was clearly sarcastic.

Response: Framing in communication is the way we structure and present information to shape how others perceive and interpret it. It‚Äôs the lens through which we ask people to view a situation, and it can dramatically influence understanding, emotions, and decisions‚Äîeven when the underlying facts remain the same. At its core, framing recognizes that there‚Äôs rarely just one ‚Äúneutral‚Äù way to communicate something. Every choice we make about what to include, what to emphasize, how to say it, and what comparisons to draw creates a frame that guides interpretation. Consider a classic example: a medical procedure with a 90% survival rate versus one with a 10% mortality rate. These statements are factually identical, but the first frame (survival) tends to make people more willing to proceed, while the second (mortality) increases anxiety and hesitation. The frame affects decision-making even though the risk is unchanged. Framing operates through several mechanisms. We select certain details while omitting others, creating a partial picture that feels complete. We choose metaphors and analogies that connect new information to familiar concepts‚Äîdescribing an argument as a ‚Äúbattle‚Äù suggests winners and losers, while calling it a ‚Äúdance‚Äù implies coordination and mutual movement. We also use language with specific emotional associations: ‚Äúfreedom fighter‚Äù versus ‚Äúterrorist,‚Äù ‚Äúundocumented immigrant‚Äù versus ‚Äúillegal alien.‚Äù In everyday life, you see framing constantly. A company announces it‚Äôs ‚Äúrightsizing‚Äù rather than conducting layoffs. A politician frames a policy as protecting freedom or ensuring fairness. Roman Appropriation of Foreign Cultures as Political Propaganda
Roman imperial culture was deeply shaped by its encounters with‚Äîand domination over‚Äîforeign peoples. Rather than rejecting external influences, Rome selectively appropriated elements of conquered cultures and recontextualized them as tools of political propaganda. Through architecture, religious imagery, public monuments, and elite self-representation, Roman leaders transformed foreign symbols into visual statements of power, legitimacy, and imperial universality. This process allowed Rome to present itself not merely as a military hegemon, but as the rightful heir to the cultural authority of the ancient world.
One of the clearest examples of this strategy can be seen in Rome‚Äôs appropriation of Egyptian culture following Augustus‚Äô conquest of Egypt in 30 BCE. Egypt carried immense symbolic weight as an ancient, sacred, and monarchic civilization. By relocating Egyptian obelisks to Rome‚Äîsuch as those erected in the Circus Maximus and Campus Martius‚ÄîAugustus physically transplanted symbols of pharaonic authority into the Roman urban landscape. Stripped of their original religious context, these monuments were repurposed to glorify Roman victory and to associate the emperor with timeless, divine kingship. Egypt thus became a visual testament to Roman dominance, while simultaneously enhancing Augustus‚Äô own political image.
Greek culture was similarly appropriated, though in a more complex manner due to its prestige. Roman elites adopted Greek art styles, philosophy, and education to portray themselves as cultivated rulers rather than crude conquerors. Temples, statues, and literary forms borrowed heavily from Greek models, yet were often infused with Roman political meanings. By mastering Greek culture, Romans claimed intellectual and moral authority over it, reframing conquest as stewardship rather than destruction. This allowed Rome to present its empire as a civilizing force, legitimizing expansion through cultural superiority.
Foreign appropriation also functioned at the level of elite self-fashioning. Such displays reinforced Rome‚Äôs identity as the center of a vast and diverse empire.
Ultimately, Roman appropriation of foreign cultures was not passive imitation but an active political strategy. By absorbing and reshaping the symbols of conquered peoples, Rome transformed cultural diversity into evidence of imperial control. Foreignness, once subdued, became a resource‚Äîone that strengthened Roman authority and projected an image of an empire destined to rule the known world.
